parts.text: Using the subject provided via PDF, make the "AI" do logical moves, not random ones

message.text: Using the subject provided via PDF, make the "AI" do logical moves, not random ones

response.value: Absolutely! Your current code uses a random move for the AI (

). To make the AI play logically, you should implement the **minimax algorithm** (as suggested in your code comments: "ETAPE 4 : Remplacer IA aléatoire par l'algorithme minimax").

Below is a **drop-in replacement** for your

function, plus the required `minimax` function. This will make the AI play optimally (never lose, always win if possible).

---

### 1. Add the Minimax Algorithm

Add this function **above** your

with the following:

```python
def ai_move():
    best_score = -float('inf')
    best_move = None
    for (i, j) in get_empty_positions(board):
        board[i][j] = "O"
        score = minimax(board, 0, False)
        board[i][j] = " "
        if score > best_score:
            best_score = score
            best_move = (i, j)
    if best_move:
        board[best_move[0]][best_move[1]] = "O"
        draw_move(best_move[0], best_move[1], "O")
```

---

**That's it!**  
Now, the AI will always play the best possible move.

---

### **Summary of changes:**
- Add the `minimax` function.
- Replace the random AI with a minimax-based AI.

---

**Tip:** If you want the AI to play less "perfectly" (for fun), you can add randomness or limit the depth, but as written, this will make it unbeatable.

Let me know if you want the code with comments or further improvements!

metadata.helpTextPrefix: You can ask me general programming questions, or chat with the following participants which have specialized expertise and can perform actions:
metadata.helpTextVariablesPrefix: You can also help me understand your question by using the following variables to give me extra context:

helpTextPostfix.value:
To have a great conversation, ask me questions as if I was a real programmer:

* **Show me the code** you want to talk about by having the files open and selecting the most important lines.
* **Make refinements** by asking me follow-up questions, adding clarifications, providing errors, etc.
* **Review my suggested code** and tell me about issues or improvements, so I can iterate on it.

You can also ask me questions about your editor selection by [starting an inline chat session](command:inlineChat.start).

Learn more about [GitHub Copilot](https://docs.github.com/copilot/using-github-copilot/getting-started-with-github-copilot?tool=vscode&utm_source=editor&utm_medium=chat-panel&utm_campaign=2024q3-em-MSFT-getstarted) in [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/overview). Or explore the [Copilot walkthrough](command:github.copilot.open.walkthrough).
